Welcome aboard the China Clipper II. Fifty years ago today, the China
Clipper, a Pan Am Martin M-130 fivina boat. taxied out into the harbor of
San Francisco Bay and took off trailing a large wake of sea spray. Bands
played and flags waved. Cheering crowds lined the shores. A flotilla of
pleasure boats dotted the harbor and small planes new overnead to
witness the historic event - the inauguration of the first commercial
transpacific airmail service from San Francisco to Manila by the China
Clipper. Recognizing the significance of the moment, President Franklin
D. Roosevelt sent a special message "conveying heartfelt congratulations
otan airminded sallor
Today, we commemorate this historic flight by retracing the route of the
China Clipper aboard a Boeing 747 Jet Clipper.
The flight of the China
Glinner Il not only celebrates nast achievements. but serves as a reminder
of the advances made in aviation. We pay tribute to the individual and
collective efforts of the men and women who pioneered Pan Am's air
routes across the Pacific. We are honored that you are joining Pan Am on
this nostalaic flight into history in salute to the China Clipper.
C. Edward Acker
Chairman
PACIFIC OCEAN
n November 22, 1935 at 3:46 pm (local time), the China
Clinner took off from the Pan American oneratina hase at
Alameda, California enroute to Manila. The route had
previously been charted by survey missions flown by Pan
Am. The 8.210-mile iournev included stops in Honolulu,
Midway, Wake and Guam Islands, arriving in Manila exactly on schedule
on November 29. Total elapsed time was 6 days, 7 hours and 46 minutes.
Total flying time was 59 hours, 48 minutes.
The China Clipper had a crew of seven with Pan Am's veteran chief
Dilot Captain Edwin C. Musick in command. This first transpacific airmail
flight carried 58 bags of mail with 110,865 letters bound for Honolulu,
Guam and Manila. Today. the China Clipper Il is carrvina approximately
180 nAn lottore

GUAM
nroute to Guam, Captain Musick radioed from the flight deck,
"Everythina was tunctionina pertectly and the China Clipper
settled down to the long 1,500-mile drive ahead. The cloud
moisture on the wings flashed every color of the spectrum and
the propellers described areat alistenina arcs as we sped ahead
in a world all to ourselves — except for the nine radio stations and the three
radio compass stations that kept their invisible fingers on us.'
Ine cnina Clipper crossed the international Date Line and arved in
Guam 45 minutes ahead of schedule. After a day of rest and Thanksgiving
dinner at the Governor's Palace, the crew of the China Clipper was ready
to embark on the final leg of their journey.

MANILA
he 1,600-mile leg from
Guam to Manila was the
dispatch from Manila. Caotain Musick
said: "As the rugged hills of the Philip-
pines appeared over the port bow
today, the crew of the China Clipper
came to a realization of the significance
of this achievement for American
aviation — a history-making 8,000-mile
flight in a four-motored transport plane
Alameda, California to Manila."
Arriving in Manila right on schedule
als.sc omocarime on vovemoen
29, the China Clipper was greeted by
exuberant crowds. Asked by curious
reponers to aescroe neinoumey,
Captain Musick simply stated: "The
flight was without incident."
